channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: 9 Detained in Bombings on Turkey Border With Syria
item.description: Turkish officials said the nine detained in the bombings that killed 46 people had been linked to the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad, a claim that Syria denies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: After Fair Trade Coffee, Fair Trade Shea
item.description: Some of the West African women who harvest shea are coming to New York this week to talk to the multinationals that buy their product about how to make sure everyone benefits.
item.dc:creator: By FRANKIE EDOZIEN
item.media:description: Women from a cooperative in Burkino Faso prepare shea butter.)

item.title: China Investigates Liu Tienan, an Official Challenged by a Journalist
item.description: China’s top anti-corruption agency said that it was investigating a senior economic policy maker, an abrupt turn in a case that had openly pitted him against an investigative journalist.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Raw Data: Deutsche Telekom, Data Use and ‘Net Neutrality’
item.description: A leading German Internet provider said it would impose hard download limits but would exempt the traffic generated by its own Internet television service.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN J. O’BRIEN

item.title: South Korea Seeks Arrest of Podcaster Choo Chin-woo
item.description: Prosecutors said the journalist Choo Chin-woo “spread false information” about President Park Geun-hye’s brother through articles and a podcast in order to block her election.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Canada Exports Mafia War to Sicily
item.description: The stereotypical image of Canada does not immediately evoke images of big time gangsters and mob war. However, the discovery of two bodies in Sicily this week suggests that Canadian criminal rivalry has even reached the birthplace of the Mafia.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Quebec police at the scene of a Mafia-linked murder on Nov. 5, 2012.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Lao She’s Art Collection Auctioned Amid Enthusiasm
item.description: A collection of paintings belonging to the writer Lao She, who killed himself in the Cultural Revolution, and his wife, the painter Hu Jieqing, were auctioned in Beijing amid considerable excitement.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screenshot from the Web site of Cultural China, www.cultural-china.com, showing the writer Lao She.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Why Putin Can’t Solve Syria
item.description: Russian analysts say Washington is kidding itself if it believes Mr. Putin can orchestrate a quick and easy Assad exit. But the crisis has increased Vladimir Putin’s standing at home and Russia’s abroad.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID ROHDE
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia, right, speaks to Secretary of State John Kerry, center, as Russia's foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, looks on, in Moscow on May 7.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
item.description: What’s on view this week in art museums around the world.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH HOPKINS
item.media:description: Niki de Saint Phalle's "Devouring Mothers," 1970, at the Moderna Museet in Stockholm.

item.title: The Lede: Updates on Pakistan’s Election
item.description: Nawaz Sharif has already declared victory, while his opponent Imran Khan has made some gains. An online video appears to show vote tampering.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Egypt's Music Revolution
item.description: A youth-driven and socially conscious music genre called mahraganat reflects social shifts sparked by the revolution that toppled President Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

item.title: Egypt’s Chaos Stirs Musical Revolution
item.description: Egypt’s rising-star rappers predated the revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak, but the turmoil since has left a huge youth population searching for voices that address issues they care about.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhammad Salah, center, known as Okka, and Ahmed Mustafa, right, known as Ortega, danced to their tracks in a Cairo suburb recently as their drummer played.

item.title: Car Bombings Kill Dozens in Center of Turkish Town Near the Syrian Border
item.description: Officials with Turkey’s government, which has backed the Syrian rebels, said the attackers belonged to a group linked to intelligence services in Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:credit: Aykut Unlupinar/Anadolu Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The site of one of the blasts on Saturday in Reyhanli, a Turkish town near the border and host to thousands of Syrian refugees.

item.title: Nawaz Sharif Set to Regain Power in Pakistan
item.description: The party led by former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, once a political exile, appeared to have enough seats to form a government easily.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Tucked in Immigration Bill, Special Deals for Some
item.description: The prospect of immigration overhaul has spurred energetic lobbying from many foreign nations seeking a little something extra, whether additional work permits or visa-free tourist visits.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC LIPTON
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea in Washington last week.

item.title: Pakistanis Vote as Violence Breaks Out
item.description: Voters turned out for a historic election as threats of attacks were borne out, with violence across the country leaving at least 21 people dead.

item.title: Berlusconi Rallies Supporters, With Defiant Words for Judges and Prosecutors
item.description: A rally on Saturday to protest two court rulings against former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi became a fresh test to a coalition of political parties formed two weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Egypt Arrests 3 in Plot to Attack Cities and an Embassy
item.description: An American diplomat said that his Egyptian counterparts told him that the United States Embassy was targeted.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Israel and Russia to Discuss Arms Sale to Syria
item.description: Concerns that Russia has a longstanding contract to deliver a sophisticated air defense system to Syria has prompted talks between Benjamin Netanyahu and Vladimir Putin in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Two Candidates Shake Up Iran’s Presidential Race as Last-Minute Entries
item.description: Iran’s presidential campaign took an unexpected turn on Saturday, when two game-changing politicians entered the race in the final minutes of a five-day registration period.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani in 2010.

item.title: Ahmed Maher of Egypt Released After Questioning
item.description: Ahmed Maher, a leader of the April 6 Youth Group, was questioned and held overnight in a high-security prison, then released Saturday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Afghanistan and U.S. Continue Talks on Future Relations
item.description: Senior American and Afghan officials met in Kabul to iron out details of a pact that defines relations after 2014, when foreign combat troops are to withdraw from Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China’s Social Media Fuel Citizen Quake Response
item.description: The rapid grass-roots response to the April earthquake in Sichaun Province reveals how far China’s nascent civil society movement has come since a major quake in 2008.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: A man repaired a tent outside his quake-damaged house last month in Sichuan Province, China.

item.title: Death Toll in Bangladesh Collapse Tops 1,100
item.description: The police say the death toll from the collapse of a garment-factory building has reached 1,115, and rescue workers are continuing to dig.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Pakistanis Explain What the Election Means to Them
item.description: A selection of comments from readers in Pakistan on what Saturday’s elections mean to them.
item.dc:creator: By SHREEYA SINHA
item.media:description: Women lined up to vote at a polling station in Dial, Pakistan, on Saturday.
